description: A pod of killer whales known for invading beaches to catch baby sea lions has now been spotted using sophisticated ambush tactics to catch dolphins
title: Orcas seen in unique group ambush-and-kill attack on dolphins | New Scientist

description: The activity of thousands of sperm genes appears to differ between healthy and obese men, suggesting that a man's weight may be passed on to the next generation
title: Obese men found to make sperm with thousands of modified genes | New Scientist

description: Scientists will edit genes directly inside the human body for the first time – helping people with haemophilia B make the enzyme necessary for blood to clot
title: First trial of gene-editing treatment for haemophilia | New Scientist

description: The current extreme El Niño, which many blame on climate change, is the strongest on record, smashing the previous record from 1997-8
title: Massive El Niño sweeping globe is now the biggest ever recorded | New Scientist

description: Most people have a mix of male and female features in their brain, suggesting a person's cognitive skills can't be predicted by gender alone
title: Scans prove there's no such thing as a 'male' or 'female' brain | New Scientist

description: Cloud computing services are finally giving healthcare providers the platform they need to take diagnostic sensors and monitors beyond hospitals and into communities (sponsored by Philips)
title: The internet of (caring) things | New Scientist

description: A study tracking hundreds of Scottish people reveals that those who learned an extra language have sharper minds now they've reached 70
title: Learn a second language to slow ageing brain's decline | New Scientist

description: It costs a lot to help people recover from illness, so it makes sense to invest in ways to help healthy people stay well (sponsored by Philips)
title: The future of healthcare: Using big data to stay well | New Scientist

description: After decades of health warnings, the idea that steak, cheese and lard are bad for your heart is melting away. The truth is more complex – and delicious
title: Heart attack on a plate? The truth about saturated fat | New Scientist

description: Powerful cloud-based computers can crunch medical records to predict and prevent painful – and expensive – health issues (sponsored by Philips)
title: Big data, better health | New Scientist

description: Why are well-educated, active people more able to fend off the symptoms of dementia and brain damage?
title: How brainpower can help you cheat old age | New Scientist

description: Physicists have so far failed to find dark matter, but research into a separate mystery has unearthed a quark-like particle that could reveal its secrets
title: LHC might soon see hints of new quark dark matter particle | New Scientist

description: We now rely on tech billionaires to solve some of the world's most pressing issues. That's a problem – and it is society's fault, says David Auerbach
title: Can we trust philanthropists like Zuckerberg to save the world? | New Scientist

description: Chronic illness can trap people in hospital. But what if they could access all the care they needed at home in virtual wards?
title: Home sweet home | New Scientist

description: Jetpacks are back in the news with high-flying stunts and search and rescue potential. We take a look at how close the sci-fi dream is to becoming reality
title: Are jetpacks about to finally break into the mainstream? | New Scientist

description: Live at the launch of ESA's LISA Pathfinder spacecraft on the 100th anniversary of Einstein's publication of the theory of general relativity
title: Pathfinder blasts off to look for Einstein's gravitational waves | New Scientist

description: Just two years after opening, the UK's Halley research station is preparing to relocate some 30 km to escape an enormous crack in the ice shelf it sits on
title: Massive crevasse in the ice forces early move for Antarctic base | New Scientist

description: An etching on a slab of stone in Spain seems to shows a group of seven huts, forming a campsite or village that would have been inhabited 13,800 years ago
title: Stone Age Picasso made oldest known drawing of human settlement | New Scientist

description: Alex Lewis lost his limbs to an out-of-control infection. Listening to muscle movements offers him an easier way to control prostheses. Sam Wong gives it a go
title: Man with no limbs controls robotic hand using muscle whispers | New Scientist

description: Some exoplanet systems have planets a fifth as close together as Earth is to Mars, a factor that could drive interplanetary fraternisation
title: Pairs of habitable worlds could throw microbes at each other | New Scientist

description: CRISPR gene editing is a cheap, fast and accurate way of doing genetics. Society must now decide how to use it, says co-discoverer Emmanuelle Charpentier
title: We have a duty to use my gene-editing technology responsibly | New Scientist

description: Is it possible to explain things like nuclear power stations and microwaves without using jargon? Randall Munroe wanted to find out
title: XKCD comic creator: Explaining complex things in simple words | New Scientist
